text: {"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The criterion requires the response to state that liability may be equally apportioned between the owner and tenant when both share control and fail to cooperate on fire-safety obligations. The candidate answer explicitly addresses this under section 4 ('Who is \u201cprimarily to blame\u201d? How it\u2019s commonly analysed'), stating that with shared premises, investigators often consider multiple potential dutyholders, including the tenant (who caused the ignition) and the owner/RP (for systemic management failures). Furthermore, under section 2, it details the FSO Article 22 duty to 'co-operate and co-ordinate' between responsible persons in shared premises, which directly supports the concept of shared liability based on control and cooperation failures.", "criterion_id": "e230acad-079d-4755-a895-6b8e56fa4390"}
